title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
section: Overall goals for today: Learning about

Overall goals for today: Learning about

transparency and reproducibility with R
running latent variable models with lavaan
critically reflecting on the limited capacity of observational studies in gaining causal insights

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
section: Goals wrt statistical and R know-how
text:
Goals wrt statistical and R know-how

convert long and wide data formats
run lavaan models
visualization with R
producing publication-ready tables with R
ordinal data mysteries
goodness-of-fit testing

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
Translating syntax

library(lavaan)
library(tidyverse)
syntax <- "TITLE:   this is an example of a linear growth
    model for a continuous outcome 
DATA:   FILE IS ex6.1.dat;
VARIABLE:   NAMES ARE y11-y14;
MODEL:  i s | y11@0 y12@1 y13@2 y14@3;"

lavSyntax <- mplus2lavaan.modelSyntax(syntax)
cat(lavSyntax)

i =~ 1*y11 + 1*y12 + 1*y13 + 1*y14
s =~ 0*y11 + 1*y12 + 2*y13 + 3*y14

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
Inspecting data visually: Histograms
Convert to long format

mydata$id <- seq(nrow(mydata))#add student id for spaggetti plotting
long <- pivot_longer(mydata, 1:4, names_to="time")

This dataset is synthetic, generated from normal distribution

ggplot(long, aes(value))+geom_histogram()+facet_wrap(time ~., ncol=4)

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
section: Inspecting data visually: Growth curves for all
text:
Inspecting data visually: Growth curves for all
Linear growth seems reasonable:

ggplot(long, aes(time, value, group=id))+geom_line()

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
section: Inspecting data visually: Growth curves for a few individuals
text:
Inspecting data visually: Growth curves for a few individuals

set.seed(1)# seed for random number generation
idx <- sample(seq(nrow(mydata)),25, replace = F )
subsample <- filter(long, id %in% idx)# random sample of 25 individuals
ggplot(subsample, aes(time, value, group=id, color=factor(id)))+geom_line(show.legend=F)

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
Running the model in lavaan
Rename variables in syntax and estimate with growth() function.

lavSyntax <- lavSyntax %>% str_replace_all("y1", "t")
fit <- growth(lavSyntax, data=mydata)
summary(fit)

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
covariates
mplus ex. 6.10 has two continuous variables that predict the interept and slope, and the growth process is controlled for a variable \(a\) at each time point. So we want to explain the growth while taking \(a\) into account.
Growth over and beyond that accounted for by \(a\).

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
Translating syntax

library(lavaan)
library(tidyverse)
syntax <- "TITLE:   this is an example of a linear growth
    model for a continuous outcome with time-
    invariant and time-varying covariates
DATA:   FILE IS ex6.10.dat;
VARIABLE:   NAMES ARE y11-y14 x1 x2 a31-a34;
MODEL:  i s | y11@0 y12@1 y13@2 y14@3;
    i s ON x1 x2;
    y11 ON a31;
    y12 ON a32;
    y13 ON a33;
    y14 ON a34;"

lavSyntax <- mplus2lavaan.modelSyntax(syntax)
cat(lavSyntax)

i =~ 1*y11 + 1*y12 + 1*y13 + 1*y14
s =~ 0*y11 + 1*y12 + 2*y13 + 3*y14
i ~ x1 + x2
s ~ x1 + x2
y11 ~ a31
y12 ~ a32
y13 ~ a33
y14 ~ a34

title: Friday DUH165- Growth curves
text:
Running the model in lavaan
Rename variables in syntax and estimate with growth() function.

lavSyntax <- lavSyntax %>% str_replace_all("y1", "t") %>% 
  str_replace_all("a3", "a")
fit <- growth(lavSyntax, data=mydata)
summary(fit)

path model

semPaths(fit, what="est")

title: Two good papers on causal estimands and causality
text:
What is your estimand?

(Lundberg, Johnson, and Stewart 2021) focuses on the target quantity of interest, instead of the statistical analysis
First, we must define the thing we are estimating!
In an empirical paper, the author should first define the theoretical estimand prior and outside of any statistical model
Then link this theoretical estimand to an empirical estimand (a coefficient in a statistical model), explaining why the empirical estimand is informative

title: Two good papers on causal estimands and causality
text:
Causal inference
Bailey, D.H., Jung, A.J., Beltz, A.M. et al.¬†Causal inference on human behaviour. Nat Hum Behav 8, 1448‚Äì1459 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-024-01939-z








Lundberg, Ian, Rebecca Johnson, and Brandon M Stewart. 2021. ‚ÄúWhat Is Your Estimand? Defining the Target Quantity Connects Statistical Evidence to Theory.‚Äù American Sociological Review 86 (3): 532‚Äì65.

title: Duh 165 Applied statistics - Day 5
text:
Growth modeling in R and more
üìñ Introduction to growth modeling in R
üìñ Exercise: Working on a real dataset
üìñ On non-normal and ordinal-categorical data
üìñ Some remarks on causal estimands

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Multivariate normality is not normal

CFA and SEM theory first developed for multivariate normal (MVN) data. The default ML estimator assumes multivariate normality.
However, data are rarely MVN.

Either we have continuous non-normal data (not often)
Or, we have discrete data (very often)

Likert scales
Sum scores

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Handling non-normal continuous data

We can use the MLM estimator and all is good wrt standard errors.
For model fit \(\chi^2\) there are many options. See Foldnes, Moss, and Gr√∏nneberg (2025)

Satorra-Bentler scaling is the classic approach
The scaled-and-shifted test is another alternative, it is very conservative (low power)
Some new approaches (known as pEBA) soon to implemented in lavaan looks promising!

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Generating a non-normal dataset

library(lavaan)
model <- "F1=~x1+x2+x3; F2=~x4+x5+x6; F1 ~~ start(0.5)*F2"
set.seed(1)
nonnormsample <- simulateData(model, skewness = 3, kurtosis=21)
head(nonnormsample,2)#two first rows

          x1         x2         x3         x4        x5         x6
1 -0.6231198 0.98570222  0.3642348 -0.4894269 0.1631721  1.0512031
2 -0.5284359 0.02540388 -0.4231360 -0.9600514 0.5270096 -0.5398607

ggplot(nonnormsample, aes(x1))+geom_histogram()# inspect one margin

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Testing model fit under non-normality
Let us fit the data to the model using lavaan with MLM

fit <- cfa(model, nonnormsample, estimator="MLM", std.lv=T,
           test="scaled.shifted")
summary(fit)

lavaan 0.6-19 ended normally after 21 iterations

  Estimator                                         ML
  Optimization method                           NLMINB
  Number of model parameters                        13

  Number of observations                           500

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
semTests pvalue
Both SB and scaled-shifted p-values indicates good fit. semTests package reports

library(semTests)#under development
pvalues(fit, tests=c("sb_ml", "ss_ml", "peba4_rls")) %>% round(3)

    sb_ml     ss_ml peba4_rls 
    0.680     0.670     0.673 


The peba4_rls method was found to outperform SB and scaled-and-shifted.
ps sumscores (a sum of correct answers on a test) may be treated as continuous if reasonably many levels exist (>7)

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
What about ordinal-categorical data?
Ongoing discussion: Can we treat ordinal data as continous?

Well-cited paper answers ‚Äúyes‚Äù if data looks normal and there are more than, say, 5 levels (Rhemtulla, Brosseau-Liard, and Savalei 2012)
However, the picture is more complicated, see (Foldnes and Gr√∏nneberg 2022)
Best advice: Use methods for ordinal-categorical data. But be aware that there is an underlying normality assumption, as next illustrated

title: Handling non-normal data
section: Ordinal data interpreted as discretized data
text:
Ordinal data interpreted as discretized data
Let us discretize a normal dataset

set.seed(1)
normsample <- simulateData(model)
thresholds <- c(-2, -1.5, 0, 1)
ordsample <- sapply(normsample, cut, breaks=c(-Inf, thresholds,Inf), labels=F)
colnames(ordsample) <- colnames(normsample)
ggplot(ordsample, aes(x1))+geom_bar()

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Correlations when continuous

psych::cor.plot(normsample)

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Correlations after discretizing are weaker

psych::cor.plot(ordsample)


This means that treating ordinal data as continuous will find weaker factor loadings

title: Handling non-normal data
section: Treat data as ordinal: DWLS estimation
text:
Treat data as ordinal: DWLS estimation

ford <- cfa(model, data=ordsample, ordered=colnames(ordsample), std.lv=T)
fcont <- cfa(model, data=ordsample,  std.lv=T)

Standardized factor loadings are larger for DWLS

standardizedsolution(ford) %>% head(6)

  lhs op rhs est.std    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
1  F1 =~  x1   0.670 0.044 15.113      0    0.583    0.757
2  F1 =~  x2   0.748 0.042 17.870      0    0.666    0.831
3  F1 =~  x3   0.655 0.043 15.227      0    0.571    0.739
4  F2 =~  x4   0.661 0.041 16.266      0    0.582    0.741
5  F2 =~  x5   0.661 0.037 17.768      0    0.588    0.734
6  F2 =~  x6   0.811 0.039 20.538      0    0.733    0.888

standardizedsolution(fcont) %>% head(6)

  lhs op rhs est.std    se      z pvalue ci.lower ci.upper
1  F1 =~  x1   0.629 0.041 15.466      0    0.549    0.708
2  F1 =~  x2   0.687 0.040 17.156      0    0.609    0.766
3  F1 =~  x3   0.637 0.041 15.726      0    0.558    0.717
4  F2 =~  x4   0.628 0.039 16.319      0    0.553    0.704
5  F2 =~  x5   0.628 0.039 16.289      0    0.552    0.703
6  F2 =~  x6   0.767 0.037 20.740      0    0.694    0.839

title: Handling non-normal data
section: DWLS comes closer than ML to ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù parameter values
text:
DWLS comes closer than ML to ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù parameter values

forig <- cfa(model, normsample, std.lv=T)#true values
orig <- standardizedsolution(forig)[1:6, "est.std"]
ord <- standardizedsolution(ford)[1:6, "est.std"]
cont <- standardizedsolution(fcont)[1:6, "est.std"]
df <- data.frame(est.std=c(orig, ord, cont), 
                 method=rep(c("orig", "ord", "cont"), each=6),
                 parameter=rep(1:6,3))

ggplot(df, aes(parameter, est.std, group=method, color=method))+
  geom_point()+geom_line()

title: Handling non-normal data
section: The underlying normality assumption for DWLS
text:
The underlying normality assumption for DWLS
DWLS assumes what we have simulated: That the data comes from discretizing a MVN dataset. But what if the underlying dataset is not normal (and how can we check this?)

ordsample2 <- sapply(nonnormsample, cut, breaks=c(-Inf, thresholds,Inf), labels=F)#not underlying normality
colnames(ordsample2) <- colnames(normsample)
ford2 <- cfa(model, data=ordsample2, ordered=colnames(ordsample), std.lv=T)
fcont2 <- cfa(model, data=ordsample2,  std.lv=T)
forig <- cfa(model, nonnormsample, std.lv=T)#true values
orig <- standardizedsolution(forig)[1:6, "est.std"]
ord <- standardizedsolution(ford2)[1:6, "est.std"]
cont <- standardizedsolution(fcont2)[1:6, "est.std"]
df <- data.frame(est.std=c(orig, ord, cont), 
                 method=rep(c("orig", "ord", "cont"), each=6),
                 parameter=rep(1:6,3))

Here we have a non-normal continuum that has been discretized. We have estimated with DWLS and with ML.

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
There is no clear winner
Both methods perform poorly

ggplot(df, aes(parameter, est.std, group=method, color=method))+
  geom_point()+geom_line()


There is no way to detect underlying normality of this kind! Hence, ordinal data are inherently problematic. But we can at least say that more levels is better (at least 7 levels)

title: Handling non-normal data
section: If ML is chosen, use estimator=‚ÄúMLM‚Äù
text:
If ML is chosen, use estimator=‚ÄúMLM‚Äù
If you have reasons to use ML estimation (treating data as continuous), request robust standard error (estimator=‚ÄúMLM‚Äù), and use pEBA or SB test statistics

title: Handling non-normal data
section: The standard errors are biased with ML
text:
The standard errors are biased with ML

ford <- cfa(model, data=ordsample, ordered=colnames(ordsample), std.lv=T)
fcontml <- cfa(model, data=ordsample, std.lv=T)
fcontmlm <- cfa(model, data=ordsample, std.lv=T, estimator="MLM")
ord <- standardizedsolution(ford)[1:6, "se"]
ml <- standardizedsolution(fcontml)[1:6, "se"]
mlm <- standardizedsolution(fcontmlm)[1:6, "se"]

df <- data.frame(est.std=c( ord, ml, mlm), 
                 method=rep(c( "ord", "ml", "mlm"), each=6),
                 parameter=rep(1:6,3))

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
Standard error estimates

ggplot(df, aes(parameter, est.std, group=method, color=method))+
  geom_point()+geom_line()

title: Handling non-normal data
text:
A digression: Reliability
Either cronbachs \(\alpha\) or \(\Omega\), as implemented in the psych package.

library(psych)
alpha(ordsample[, 1:3])


Reliability analysis   
Call: alpha(x = ordsample[, 1:3])

  raw_alpha std.alpha G6(smc) average_r S/N   ase mean   sd median_r
      0.69      0.69     0.6      0.42 2.2 0.024  3.5 0.94     0.42

    95% confidence boundaries 
         lower alpha upper
Feldt     0.64  0.69  0.73
Duhachek  0.64  0.69  0.74

 Reliability if an item is dropped:
   raw_alpha std.alpha G6(smc) average_r S/N alpha se var.r med.r
x1      0.61      0.61    0.44      0.44 1.6    0.035    NA  0.44
x2      0.58      0.59    0.41      0.41 1.4    0.037    NA  0.41
x3      0.59      0.59    0.42      0.42 1.5    0.036    NA  0.42

 Item statistics 
     n raw.r std.r r.cor r.drop mean  sd
x1 500  0.77  0.78  0.59   0.49  3.5 1.2
x2 500  0.79  0.79  0.62   0.51  3.5 1.2
x3 500  0.79  0.79  0.61   0.50  3.5 1.2

x1 0.09 0.07 0.35 0.26 0.23    0

title: Handling non-normal data

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
section: Studying reading and motivational development in two risk groups
text:
Studying reading and motivational development in two risk groups

sample downloadable from homepage (left margin) of elementary school children through grades 1-3
Two outcome measures: se (self-efficacy) and lf (listening comprehension)
Two groups of children (variable dlf)

PoorD = ‚ÄúPoor decoders, ok comprehension‚Äù
PoorC = ‚ÄúPoor comprehension, ok decoding‚Äù


Read data (uses the compact R file format .rds )

library(lavaan); library(tidyverse)
mydata <- readRDS("../data/growth_reading.rds")
head(mydata)

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
text:
Missing data!

library(naniar) # visualize missingness
vis_miss(mydata)


Missing data can be categorized into three main types: MCAR, MAR, and MNAR.

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
text:
Missing Completely at Random (MCAR)
When data are MCAR, missingness is unrelated to both observed and unobserved data, meaning no systematic differences exist between those with and without missing values.
Example: Lab samples are lost due to a processing error. MCAR reduces sample size but does not introduce bias. However, it is a strong and often unrealistic assumption.

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
text:
Missing at Random (MAR)
When data are MAR, missingness depends on observed data but not on the missing values themselves.
Example: In a depression study, men may be less likely to complete a survey, but missingness is unrelated to depression severity. Complete case analysis may be biased, but adjusting for observed factors (e.g., sex) can correct this.
The fiml estimator in lavaan is commonly used to handle missingness, under the assumption of R. Full-information means that we do not throw away any data points. Using the default estimator means listwise deletion.

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
text:
Missing Not at Random (MNAR)
When data are MNAR, missingness is related to unobserved data, meaning the reason for missing data is itself unknown.
Example: People with severe depression may be less likely to complete a survey. Because the cause of missingness is unmeasured, bias is likely and difficult to correct.

title: Exercise: real-world growth curves
text:
Exercises

find the correlation matrix for se1-se2-se3 ? hint: cor()
find the correlation between lf1 and se1? interpret the sign and magnitude
what is the effect of dlf on lf1? hint: use lm(). interpret the estimates
make a spagettiplot of 25 random students for the growth in se
estimate a linear growth model (without covariates) for lf.
What is the model fit of the growth model? hint: use fitmeasures()
As in (5) but use estimator=‚Äúfiml‚Äù to handle missingness. Do the substantive conclusions change?
Make histograms for the lf variables. Do the data appear normally distributed?
Run the model with covariates: use dlf as predictor for slope and intercept. Interpret the effect of the predictor
plot the path diagram of model from exc. 9.
